TextEquiv.Unicode: But the scripture saieth: The Lorde
vexed Pharao and all his house with
great plagues, because of Sara Abra
hams wife. Lo here the king of Aegypt
is punished with gevous plagues for
his adultery: and yet he knew not that
Sara was Abrahams wife: how great
plagues therfore are prepared for the
men that wittingly & willingly with
out all shame commit adulterie? To
Abimelech king of the Philistines the
Lord doth say: Loe thou shalt die be
cause of the woman, which thou hast
taken away from her husbande. And
yet this king also had taken away Sa
ra, not knowing that shee was Abra
hams wife. Joseph beeing provoked to
adulterie by his maisters wife, doeth
simply saye: Howe shoulde I doe this
great wickednesse, and sinne against
God? Everie worde doth beare some
weight. For adulterie is an heynous
sinne. Whereuppon in the Booke of
Job wee finde these wordes of Job him
selfe. If mine heart have bin decei
ved by a woman, or if I have layde
waite at my neighbors doore, then
let my wife bee an other mansharlot,
and let other men have to do with her.
For this is a wickednesse and sinne
that is worthie to be judged to death.
Yea, it is a fire that utterly should con
sumer and roote out all mind increase.
Job saith, that hee hath not onelie not
committed adultery, but that hee hath
not so much at any time as once given
the attempte to defile an other mans
wife. He confesseth that adultery is a
sin, & so grievous an offence, taht it do
eth deserve to have ye adulterers wife
to be defiled with adultery. He addeth,
that adultery is a fire that utterly co
sumeth and dovoureth al thinges, and
lastly that it is a sinne to be judged &
punished by death.
Moreover Salomon the wisest of al

But the scripture saieth: The Lorde vexed Pharao and all his house with great plagues, because of Sara Abra hams wife. Lo here the king of Aegypt is punished with gevous plagues for his adultery: and yet he knew not that Sara was Abrahams wife: how great plagues therfore are prepared for the men that wittingly & willingly with out all shame commit adulterie? To Abimelech king of the Philistines the Lord doth say: Loe thou shalt die be cause of the woman, which thou hast taken away from her husbande. And yet this king also had taken away Sa ra, not knowing that shee was Abra hams wife. Joseph beeing provoked to adulterie by his maisters wife, doeth simply saye: Howe shoulde I doe this great wickednesse, and sinne against God? Everie worde doth beare some weight. For adulterie is an heynous sinne. Whereuppon in the Booke of Job wee finde these wordes of Job him selfe. If mine heart have bin decei ved by a woman, or if I have layde waite at my neighbors doore, then let my wife bee an other mansharlot, and let other men have to do with her. For this is a wickednesse and sinne that is worthie to be judged to death. Yea, it is a fire that utterly should con sumer and roote out all mind increase. Job saith, that hee hath not onelie not committed adultery, but that hee hath not so much at any time as once given the attempte to defile an other mans wife. He confesseth that adultery is a sin, & so grievous an offence, taht it do eth deserve to have ye adulterers wife to be defiled with adultery. He addeth, that adultery is a fire that utterly co sumeth and dovoureth al thinges, and lastly that it is a sinne to be judged & punished by death. Moreover Salomon the wisest of al
men saith: May a man take fire in his
bosome & his clothes not bee brent?
Or can one goe uppon hot coales, and
his feete not bee burnt: Even so hee
that goeth into his neighbours wife,
and toucheth her, cannot be unguil
tie. Men doe not utterly despise a
theese, that stealeth to satisfie his
soule when he is hungrie: But if he
may be gotten, he restoreth agayne
seven times as much, or else hee ma
keth recompence with all the sub
staunce of his house. But who so com
mitteth adulterie with a woman, hee
lacketh understanding: and hee that
doth it destroieth his owne soule. He
getteth himselfe a plague and disho
nour, and his reproch shall never bee
put out. For the jealousie and wrath
of the man will not be intreated ney
ther accepteth hee the person of anye
Mediatour, nor recieveth anie giftes,
howe great forever they bee. In these
words of Salomon many things are to
be noted. First as it cannot otherwise
be, but that fire must burn the garmet
wherein it is carried: so no man can
commit adulterie without damage &
daunger of further punishment. Se
condarily comparison is made betwixt
a theef & an adulterer: not that theft is
therby defended, but because theeves,
although they bee infamous, doe seeme
yet to sinne a great deale lesse than a
dulterers do. For a theefe may make
satisfaction by restoring ye worth of the
thing that he stole, to him, from whom
hee stole it away: but for adulterie no
amends can be made. And what is hee
that woulde not rather wishe to have
Theeves ransacke his Chest, and take
awaye his substaunce, than to have
his wife his dealing, defiled with ad
ulterie?
Moreover Salomo calleth the adul
terer madde and without understan

men saith: May a man take fire in his bosome & his clothes not bee brent? Or can one goe uppon hot coales, and his feete not bee burnt: Even so hee that goeth into his neighbours wife, and toucheth her, cannot be unguil tie. Men doe not utterly despise a theese, that stealeth to satisfie his soule when he is hungrie: But if he may be gotten, he restoreth agayne seven times as much, or else hee ma keth recompence with all the sub staunce of his house. But who so com mitteth adulterie with a woman, hee lacketh understanding: and hee that doth it destroieth his owne soule. He getteth himselfe a plague and disho nour, and his reproch shall never bee put out. For the jealousie and wrath of the man will not be intreated ney ther accepteth hee the person of anye Mediatour, nor recieveth anie giftes, howe great forever they bee. In these words of Salomon many things are to be noted. First as it cannot otherwise be, but that fire must burn the garmet wherein it is carried: so no man can commit adulterie without damage & daunger of further punishment. Se condarily comparison is made betwixt a theef & an adulterer: not that theft is therby defended, but because theeves, although they bee infamous, doe seeme yet to sinne a great deale lesse than a dulterers do. For a theefe may make satisfaction by restoring ye worth of the thing that he stole, to him, from whom hee stole it away: but for adulterie no amends can be made. And what is hee that woulde not rather wishe to have Theeves ransacke his Chest, and take awaye his substaunce, than to have his wife his dealing, defiled with ad ulterie?
